page.title: 04THE CLOCKS OF STROUD
page.content: Sim's Clock is a well-known local landmark,built in the 1920's at the junction of the five roads in the centre of Stroud.Two of the roads,John Street and Russell Street were named after Lord John Russel, the great reformer, who was once M.P.for Stroud. 'Town Time'is to be found on the wall between to shops near the junction of four roads.This time-piece,originally a clock-maker's regulator,was made in 1858.The production of railway timetables made it essential that time should be the same all over the country; previously time had not been standardised. The Black Boy Jack Clock was made by John Miles of Kendrick Street in 1774.The clock has the figure of a negro dressed in a bay leaf type skirt ,in front of which is a bell hit by a club in the black boy's right hand.
